description.narrative:
Current students: With a student population of over 4.000 spread across five faculties, UP is one of the fastest growing Higher Learning Institutions in Rwanda. The demographic background of the students is that a majority of them come from low income earning families that can hardly cater for their needs at campus. The students have very limited job opportunities while at campus. Besides, five of the faculties are non business, offering non entrepreneurial, non commercial and non business subjects. The starting of this project was therefore a blessing to fill the missing gap among students.
Alumni UP has to-date graduated over 600, whilst the economy of Rwanda is growing, the growth is not fast enough to match the population growth. There are limited job opportunities available to the graduates of tertiary institutions, though they are equipped with both practical and theory capabilities to handle several jobs. UP- Spark project retrains the students with practical entrepreneurship skills to enable students to start their own businesses. The revolving fund has proven vital to assist as startup capital to students especially in times when they lack mortgage to get loans from financial institutions. Youths Currently, Youths count for more than 145,000 of the population in Nyagatare District. They are also among the vulnerable groups, especially the school dropouts and most of them are jobless and a few are employed as casual laborers. This group lacks basic entrepreneurial skills to enable them start meaningful businesses and cannot access loans due to the fact that they lack mortgage. UP- Spark project will undoubtedly bridge this gap. Umutara Polytechnic (UP) is a tertiary learning institution established by the Rwandan Eastern Province community in 2006 to address its developmental problems and avail learning facilities for thousands of post-secondary school young people in the region and the country at large. It offers training at degree level in agriculture, veterinary medicine, engineering, ICT, and business studies in addition to offering advisory services to the community of Eastern Province.
UP however faces several capacity problems. There is very few (less than 5%) local academic staff members qualified to teach at degree level in the sciences field. This poses a serious risk to sustainability of the Polytechnics programs including a heavy financial burden owing to relatively high expatriate staff salaries. There is therefore an urgent need to address this situation by availing more training opportunities to local staff for postgraduate training coupled with coaching by senior expatriate staff.
Few job opportunities are available to the graduates of tertiary institutions. Whilst the economy of Rwanda is growing, the growth is not fast enough to match the population growth rate. Taking cues from this scenario, Umutara Polytechnic introduced a business management course in the sciences program. However this was not streamlined in the whole curriculum and most of the staff members do not have skills in entrepreneurship necessary to teach, motivate and cultivate an entrepreneurship culture within the institution. UP therefore seeks to review its curriculum with assistance from an expert so as to streamline entrepreneurship as well as build capacity among staff in entrepreneurship training and coaching, strategic planning, performance management, ICT and in lobbying and advocacy.
Start-up capital is difficult to secure for graduates without collateral. Grants are therefore necessary to initiate entrepreneurs. Grants will avail examples of viable business for others to see and hence motivate them to start their own businesses once they see a working example.
Rwanda generally has few professionals in many scientific disciplines and it will be difficult for people venturing into value addition projects in these fields to obtain quality advice. A coaching and nurturing program using oversees volunteers and senior staff at the polytechnic will be necessary to initiate the entrepreneurs.
The intervention discussed above will go a long way in alleviating poverty and creating employment if implemented. Otherwise social unrests like those of Egypt and Tunisia may result if young people have no economic activity to do. The quality of life is also threatened as a population increased much faster than the economic growth rate.
We undertake the above problems with aim of developing our beneficiaries to meet their needs and sustainable development of the individuals and UP as a whole. Contribute to the Government priority objective as articulated in VISION 2020 for poverty eradication ion and employment creation.
